info:
This example uses a blank template with
the IIFE build of the front-end client.

It does not use any front-end framework, just
pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

The IIFE build should be included using a link
tag in your HTML.

name: Send a msg
info:
Send a simply msg to the front-end.

The default front-end template code will display the msg
using HTML formatting, no coding required.

name: Reload
info:
Sends a pre-formatted msg to the front-end that
causes the page to reload itself.

payload: "This is the payload from the inject node! Random number: " & $formatInteger($random()*100, "0")

name: Notification
info:
Overlays a message on top of your UI.

The message removes itself after a couple of seconds.

You can change the options property to change the look
of the displayed message.

name: New Card
info:
Inserts a pure HTML "card" into a div called `#more`.
If that div does not exist, will add to the bottom of the HTML.

Firstly attempts to remove the div so that you only ever have 1.

An example of using uibuilder's dynamic UI configuration-driven
building capabilities without the need for any fancy nodes or
frameworks. Pure HTML. But you can still utilise the extra
features of your favourite framework too if you like!

name: uibuilder standard output
info:
This shows the data coming out of the
uibuilder node's Port #1 (top) which is
the standard output.

Here you will see any standard msg sent from
your front-end code.

name: uibuilder control output
info:
This shows the data coming out of the
uibuilder node's Port #2 (bottom) which is
the control output.

Here you will see any control msg either sent
by the node itself or from the front-end library.

For example the "client disconnect" and
"client connect" messages. Or the "visibility"
messages from the client.

Loop the "client connect", "cache replay" and
"cache clear" messages back to a `uib-cache`
node before the input to uibuilder in order
to control the output of the cache.

name: Low-code report building with the help of uibuilder \n Chk Description in each node & in here \n You need to add a line to the HTML so that the Markdown output works correctly, see within
info:
To get the Markdown outputs to display,
please add the following line to the html
file before the reference to uibuilder's
library:

```
<script defer src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/markdown-it@latest/dist/markdown-it.min.js">/* Allows Markdown to be used in msg._ui */</script>
```

---

This example starts with the standard IIFE 
uibuilder template. You will note, however,
that you can remove all of the body HTML
and it will still work.

This is because all of the important text,
tables and layout are created dynamically
using a standardised configuration schema.

The schema used by uibuilder is actually
quite similar, at least in concept, to that
used by pdfmaker which was the inspiration
for this example. I didn't know about pdfmaker
when I designed the config-driven aspects of
uibuilder and it is comforting to know that I
came up with a similar solution to a similar
problem.

Output to HTML is far more flexible than
output to PDF via pdfmaker though and it will
continue to grow and improve as HMTL and CSS do.

You can still output the resulting page to
PDF very easily though.

---

Full documentation for uibuilder's low-code,
configuration-driven UI creation capabilities
is available in the Tech Docs:

https://totallyinformation.github.io/node-red-contrib-uibuilder/#/uibuilder.module?id=dynamic-data-driven-html-content-1
